Good afternoon.  
 
This is Harry Smith, filling in for Katie. 
 
Those wildfires are continuing to scorch their way
  through the woodlands of Northern California.  
  But firefighters finally have good weather on their side, which may be
  helping to slow the blaze.  Bill Whitaker will have details from near Lake Tahoe. 
 
In Washington,
  President Bush has lost another key ally in the war against Iraq, Sen. Richard Lugar.  Lugar
  has announced that he believes the president’s Iraq strategy is not working and that he
  thinks it’s time for the United States to scale back its
  military involvement in the war.  What does this mean for the White House? 
  Chief White House correspondent Jim Axelrod will report.  
 
Some of Washington’s
  most mysterious secrets are contained in the files of the CIA that have been
  sealed for decades – until now.  Today, many of those files were opened
  for the first time, most dating from the days of the Cold War.  National
  Security correspondent David Martin will give us a first look at what’s
  inside, and the secrets they reveal.   
 
On Capitol Hill, hearings began today on the
  long-term harm some well-known NFL players are experiencing from their years
  on the field.  Correspondent Cynthia Bowers will begin a two-part series on
  some of the serious damages these players are experiencing – from
  concussions to brain injury – and what is or is not being done about
  it.     
 
And our Byron Pitts will have the latest on the
  circumstances surrounding the shocking deaths of WWF star Chris Benoit, his
  wife and 7-year-old-son – deaths which authorities are describing as an
  apparent murder-suicide.  
 
 
See you tonight,
 




Harry Smith
